text:
THE NOMINATIONS.

The nominations for the Town Council for the ensuing year were held in the Council Chamber on the 25th inst., from 9 o'clock till 12 noon. A copy of the proceedings was printed in the election papers handed to all voters at the polls.

Dr. Bain, nominated by T. N. Campbell and seconded by J. F. Betts.
Mr. Thos. Knowles, by J. O. Davis and A. L. Sifton.

ELECTION RESULTS.

Ward No. I.—L. J. McPhail, nominated by E. Dooner and seconded by H. B. Macdonald.
Joseph Courtney, by T. O. Davis and R. C. Wigmore.
Ward No. II.—J. L. Johnson, nominated by W. J. Macdonald and seconded by W. J. Carter.
T. E. Baker, by J. D. Maveety and W. Drain.
Jim Knowles, by J. F. Betts and Jas. Sinclair.
Sam. McLeod, by T. O. Davis and Jas. Macdonald.

Ward No. III.—R. C. Wigmore, nominated by A. L. Sifton and seconded by Harold E. Ross.
John Carter, by Jas. Macdonald and W. J. Carter.
T. O. Davis, by A. L. Goodfellow and N. A. McKenzie.
Richard Gwynne, by Wm. J. Carter and Harold E. Ross.
Ward No. IV.—Chas. Mair, nominated by T. O. Davis and seconded by J. E. Murray.
T. J. Agnew, by John McTaggart and James Macarthur.
R. C. Wigmore, by Wm. J. Carter and J. D. Haasdonk.

Mr. Gwynne withdrew after the nominations closed, and Mr. Mair has since filled his place as Returning Officer, but he has not been signed according to the Ordinance his name should have been signed. We think it is a great mistake for electors to nominate candidates for civic honours without having given notice in part of the person's willingness to stand. If a man wishes to be a candidate let him stand himself and if not let him bring someone else forward; and if not let each ward nominate their own candidates.

THE ELECTION.

The election for mayor and councillors took place on Monday last and passed off very quietly. The contest for mayor was between Mr. McPhail, who was nominated in opposition to Dr. Bain, withdrew before the election began.

In Ward No. I, although Mr. Courtney was nominated he virtually was not in the field. The race was in that ward was over for Mr. McPhail.

Ward No. II was only contested. Sam. McLeod withdrew at the commencement, thus leaving the field to Mr. Joseph Courtney and David Macdonald.

In Ward No. IV Mr. Chas. Mair, with draw leaving the field to Messrs. Agnew and W. R. Gwynne and resulted in the return of Mr. Agnew by a majority of one.

The following is the result of the poll:

WARD NO. I.

McPhail...16
Courtney...10

WARD NO. II.

Knowles...41
Johnson...33
Baker...32

WARD NO. III.

Stewart...36
Maclean...28
Wigmore...26

WARD NO. IV.

Agnew...9
Gunn...9

The council for 1888 will be:
Mayor—Dr. Bain, Couns. Stewart, Agnew, McPhail, Knowles, Johnson and Davis.

SASKATCHEWAN
DIRECTORY

At the request of a number of influential citizens of Prince Albert, who desire to be informed at once about the first issue, we have been directed by the publishers to make the following announcement throughout the district setting therefor a special rate of postage of five cents per copy for the year 1885.

It is respectfully requested of the citizens of Prince Albert, and of Bathfield, an allusion to the above announcement, to send in their names as soon as possible, and post them promptly.

No pains will be spared to make the publication of this directory as complete as possible, and to give it the widest circulation possible.

Orders for copies of Directory may be sent direct to Mr. J. Dunn or T. N. Campbell, proprietors of the Prince Albert Times, or to any person who has not sent in their addresses, will please do so immediately.

Those who have already sent in their names are requested to contribute articles descriptive of the various localities included in the directory, and also to send in their names as soon as possible.

The publication will be inserted at the rate of five cents per copy, and subscription price to advertisers will be thirty-five cents per year.

H. T. MacDougall
Prince Albert, Sask.

READ, READ.

The North West Farmer will be mailed to new subscribers, from now to December 31st, 1885, for the regular yearly subscription of twenty-five cents. Subscribers, when renewing, will be marked up to date.

The publication is now in its third volume, and contains the best agricultural information in the world.

The publishers are desirous of making the North West Farmer and the North-West, both in Canada and the United States, the best Agricultural and Stock Breeding publication in the North West. It is a 34 page monthly, handsomely got up, and a thoroughly practical publication, full of valuable information in its departments, and the latest and best farming news from all over the country.

The departments are:

AMONG THE FARMERS.
Containing descriptions of the farms (stock and agricultural) visited during the past month.

AGRICULTURAL SOCIETIES.
Containing the news of the latest doings of the different agricultural societies.

LIVE STOCK.
Veterinary Department—In which veterinary practitioners will be answered free of charge by a prominent Veterinarian.

The Dairy, Poultry and Pet Stock.
Entertainment, Milking, The Field, Gardening, Milling, The Garden and Forestry, Game and Sports, Fishing, etc., received.

Exchange Mart.
With prices, answers to questions and Answers.

The Markets.
The department is supplied by the best market men, who are themselves practical farmers, and who are in constant communication with the best farmers in the country.

The North West Farmer is edited by the best agricultural papers in the country, and is submitted by all to be the most reliable source of information on all facts of interest to the farmer.

It is the best guide to be had, and the cheapest and safest guide in the North West. It is the best guide to be had, and the cheapest and safest guide in the North West.

HOW TO SUBSCRIBE.
Enclose twenty-five cents for a year's subscription, and post to every place in the world.

N.W. WEST FARMER.

Winnipeg, Man.
